Award.AwardTitle: REU Site for Oregon Marine Science: From upper estuaries to the deep sea.
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides renewed funding for a Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program at Oregon State University. The program will support eighteen students/year during a ten week summer research program with 9 interns located on the Oregon coast at Hatfield Marine Science Center (HMSC) in Newport, Oregon and 9 interns in the College of Oceanic and Atmospheric Sciences (COAS) at the main OSU campus in Corvallis. The major field for this REU site is broadly defined as marine science, ranging from diverse biological and ecological topics (focused at HMSC) through the physical sciences (marine aspects of physics, geology, chemistry, and atmospheric science at COAS). The major objectives of the REU program are to i) provide students with the opportunity to experience research in marine science and an understanding of its interdisciplinary nature; ii) provide students with a unique educational opportunity and exposure to a wide range of marine science; and iii) increase participation in and access to marine studies for under-represented groups. Interns have directed research projects, a required report and oral presentation, and are encouraged to present at regional or national meetings. Additional activities include seminar series, field sampling, interaction with graduate students and related intern programs, career development training, scientific ethics discussions, and exchanges to learn about other interdisciplinary research conducted in Oregon's diverse environments.

The site is co-funded by the Department of Defense in partnership with the NSF REU program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award under the NSF Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site program funded research internships and training in ocean, earth, and atmospheric sciences for 61 undergraduates. The intellectual merit of this award was advancement of basic research in ocean, earth, and atmospheric science through undergraduate student engagement with university and agency (NOAA, EPA) scientists in a collaborative and supportive environment.   Student research projects have contributed to our understanding of the Earth, ocean, and atmosphere, including:

  • Effects of ocean hypoxia on body condition of juvenile flatfish
  • Thermal evolution of magmatic centers with changes in mantle-crustal interaction
  • Use of biomarkers in identifying sources and fate of organic matter in fluvial and shelf sediments
  • At sea sampling and identification in baseline survey of macroinfaunal invertebrate community at potential wave energy site off the Oregon coast
  • Development of remote sensing techniques to measure wave height
  • Role of internal tides in nutrient transport, mixing, and pollutant dispersion
  • Characterization of microbial communities in methane seeps and other benthic habitats
  • Effects of river discharge rate on estuarine currents and stratification
  • Measurement of nutrient flux in low and high marsh habitat of a coastal estuary
  • Age and emplacement rates of large igneous provinces
  • Remote sensing of river plumes in the coastal ocean and their effects on coastal upwelling, mixing, and ocean stratification
  • Analysis of high-resolution video transects for habitat associations of benthic fish
  • Variations in coastal upwelling, productivity, and hypoxia on the Oregon continental shelf
  • Geophysical site characterization for geothermal energy exploration at Newberry Volcano, Oregon
  • Fault motion and age in the Klamath Basin, Oregon, and implications for the earthquake risk to Klamath Falls and nearby communities
  • Measuring oxygen flux near the sea floor of the ocean using Eddy Correlation, a noninvasive and novel approach

The broader impacts of this award were promotion and retention of a talented and diverse pool of undergraduates in science.  Alumni of this program have received many accolades including the prestigious Goldwater scholarship, National Science Foundation research fellowships, and Geological Society of America research grant. This REU program has increased participation of women (69% of our interns were women) and minorities (38% of our interns were from under-represented racial groups) in the ocean, earth, and atmospheric sciences and contributed to national goals of a broader, more diverse, and inclusive workforce in science and technology.  46% of students who completed a research internship in this project have obtained or are now pursuing graduate or professional degrees in science.  Other REU program alumni are now teaching science in public schools, in medical professions such as nursing, or employed in industry.
